Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I could feel my phone buzzing in my apron pocket, the vibration insistent and familiar. My husband’s name flashed on the screen, and I knew he needed me—he’d barely slept in days, and every message was a lifeline. He was counting on me to be there, to listen, to reassure him that things would be okay. But right now, I was standing behind a new client, her eyes darting anxiously between her reflection and me. She hesitated, then said quietly, “I thought it would be warmer… more honey than ash.” My heart squeezed. I could see the disappointment in her face, and I knew how important it was to make her feel heard and cared for. My manager always said, “A happy client is a returning client.” I wanted to fix it, to make her smile, but my mind kept drifting to my husband’s crisis, his need for comfort. I felt torn, the weight of both worlds pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention, each expecting me to be everything they needed—right now.
